awd_titl_txt: Conference: Maurice Auslander Distinguished Lectures and International Conference
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the 2023 and 2024 Maurice Auslander International Conference, which will be held at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, Quissett Campus in Woods Hole, Massachusetts, USA from April 26 to May 1, 2023, and again in the last week of April, 2024.The Maurice Auslander International Conference, held annually since 2002, is intended to be a center of activity for the representation theory of finite dimensional algebras in the United States. The conference will be a combination workshop/conference/student presentation event. It will serve three principal objectives: to improve understanding of basic background knowledge in the field of representations of finite dimensional algebras and related topics, to keep participants up to date on the newest developments in the field, and to give young American researchers an opportunity to showcase their results in front of an international audience. 

Maurice Auslander was an influential mathematician at Brandeis University, widely known for his work in the representation theory of finite dimensional algebras. The Maurice Auslander International Conference brings together mathematicians from Representation Theory and related areas of Combinatorics, Invariant Theory, Commutative Algebra, Homological Algebra, and Mathematical Physics. Each day of the conference will start with an expository lecture by a known international expert in various fields of Algebra, Combinatorics or related fields, keeping to the central theme of Representation Theory. This will be followed by one or two student presentations explaining the results that the students have obtained for their PhD thesis. The rest of the lectures will be traditional conference talks. Information on the upcoming conference, as well as records for  previous years, can be found at http://www.northeastern.edu/martsinkovsky/p/MADL/MADL.html.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
With continued funding from the National Science Foundation, the Maurice Auslander Distinguished Lectures and International Conference has become a major international event centered on representation theory with applications to cluster combinatorics and data analysis. This NSF grant was used to run the Auslander Conference in 2023 and 2024. The conferences were held at Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, Quissett Campus from April 26 to May 1, 2023, and April 24-29, 2024. The major goals of these conferences were to make progress in Mathematics by bringing together researchers from different but related fields to give a large number of lectures from different points of view. For example, Hadleigh Frost, a Mathematical Physicist from Oxford, gave a very inspiring lecture that was accessible to the general Algebra audience and promoted very lively discussions about the role of Physics in Representation Theory. Vitor Gulisz, a student from Boston and others presented new ideas about what is known as "higher homological algebra", an exciting new area of mathematics. Another goal of these conferences is to bring junior and senior researchers together, so that the more experienced mathematicians can give advice and mentorship to their younger counterparts. Also, these new PhDs and students and other young researchers have the opportunity to make new contacts, especially with established mathematicians, which will further their careers and may even lead to future employment opportunities. For example, Peter Jorgensen, a very influential mathematician at Aarhus University, was very impressed with the lecture of Emre Sen, a young mathematician from Iowa, and now the two of them are writing a paper together.
At the 2024 Auslander Conference, Ben Blum-Smith a young researcher from NYU Center for Data Science made contact with Harm Derksen from Northeastern University and they are writing two papers together on a topic of common interest, namely, "invariant theory". Ben Blum-Smith also has a popular YouTube channel that explains the value of Mathematics to the world and also explains invariant theory. Dan Nakano from the University of Georgia, who was an invited speaker at the 2023 Auslander Conference also has a YouTube channel on which he posted many of the lectures from that conference. The Auslander Conferences were very successful at promoting collaborations and research. Many new results were obtained as a result and they are being published. NSF funding was crucial to enable the conferences to continue to achieve these goals.
